description: From Middle English ryver, river, rivere, from Anglo-Norman rivere, from Old French riviere, from Vulgar Latin *rīpāria (“riverbank, seashore, river”), from Latin rīpārius (“of a riverbank”), from Latin rīpa (“river bank”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₁reyp- (“to scratch, tear, cut”). Doublet of riviera and rivière. Displaced native Old English ēa.

entries.meaning: A large and often winding stream which drains a land mass, carrying water down from higher areas to a lower point, oftentimes ending in another body of water, such as an ocean or in an inland sea.
examples: Occasionally rivers overflow their banks and cause floods.

entries.meaning: Any large flow of a liquid in a single body.
(poker) The last card dealt in a hand.
examples: He called instantly but was too ashamed to show until the river.

entries.meaning: (typography) A visually undesirable effect of white space running down a page, caused by spaces between words on consecutive lines happening to coincide.

verbs.description: river (third-person singular simple present rivers, present participle rivering, simple past and past participle rivered)

entries.meaning: (poker) To improve one’s hand to beat another player on the final card in a poker game.
examples: Johnny rivered me by drawing that ace of spades.
